content: I'm pretty sure test 4 has a mistake?
The letter 'Y' appears in only one validator, none of the test cases. This makes it easy to pass all the test cases and yet fail a validator.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is perfect for shortest and fastest clash

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Lots of spelling errors which make the problem hard to understand. What's "dec" value? The test cases are not great (I think there should be more simple ones). Additionally I think there are already problems like this but that are implemented better.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: The task was not prepared properly. 
You should mark your contribution as "Work In Progress", apply all suggestions, and only then submit it for validation.

Issues:
1. Bad grammar in the "output" section (mixed French and English).
2. The "constraints" block is a bit messy: you don't need to repeat the problem statement there; input string has integer upper/lower bounds (I guess you meant length there, but it's unclear); you don't need to provide limits for output there unless it's something related to integer overflow; you specify n as greater than zero, but one of your validators has 0 as a result.
3. The "goal" part is short but not sweet. There is a lack of punctuations and the structure of the example section could've been a bit better (e.g. each example in a separate line).
4. 'Y' is not a vowel.

You should clarify in the statement if 'y' is considered a vowel.
It's "example", not "exemple".
Also, fix the statement as Flaaamort described below.

This is a classic simple clash. Good. Here is some point to fix/improve before approval:

al characters -> all characters.
"Find the sum of the ascii code of all characters of the given string which are not vowels."

The examples are given by the test cases.

Input: A string.
No need to repeat "the input is".

Output: The sum of the ascii code of all characters which are not vowels.
witch -> which, we sum the ascii codes, not the ascii characters.

Constraints: The size of the given string is less than 512.
The same code should work for an empty string. The vowels part is part of the goal/output, not needed in constraints. The constraint on the value of the output comes from the constraint on the given string. No need to add it explicitly.

Tests and Validators pairs should be variations of same test. It is not the case for Test 1 and Test 4. You can add more tests if you want.
Il faudrait préciser que tu considères le 'y' comme voyelle  par ce que j'ai l'impression que ce n'est toujours le cas en anglais.

vogels => vowels, witch => which
Constraints are supposed to give the scale indication of inputs/output (in your case max input length, min/max output values)
paired tests and validators should be variations of the same test, that's not the case.
"maman va au marché" => 'é' is not an ASCII character, explain what you tried to do there.

Finally, if you fix those mistakes in your puzzle, what can be learnt from it?

Agree. I was in a clash that most people got 75% simply because they ignored the Y character in the statement.

The statement is in English, so I guess people generally do not expect Y as a vowel.

The clash:
https://www.codingame.com/clashofcode/clash/report/1823536bb35649fda4dd3294739f9067d722169
